body:
This will open that file in the buffer with the cursor at the specified line number.

Basically, implement the functionality of https://github.com/bogado/file-line

Better yet is to accept also `:<line>:<column>`, as many programs output that format.

comment_data.body:
That plugin doesn't describe how to even use it. Is it for command line arguments only? Can you provide some specific use cases?

Are you aware of `gF`?

Big :+1: from me

@fdinoff - just one correction, the plugin you refer to works not only when loading vim but also from within vim. 

```
vi test:34:4
```

and then within vim normal mode:

```
:e trial:12:34
```

@justinmk - this is akin to acme's ability to fuzzily match the file under a [right mouse click](http://youtu.be/dP1xVpMPn8M?t=9m30s) ~~and is definitely something I Neovim itself needs to provide support for, natively or at least a hook. Right now, the `file-line` plugin has to rather messily hook `BufferRead` and `BufferNew`... and ends up bumping into issues [like this](https://github.com/bogado/file-line/pull/24) as a result. Some means of hooking in before a file read is attempted seems cleanest. Or alternatively, don't provide any hook and just go with the GNU standard for now (the number of error formats should really be small, ~1):~~

_Edit_: this hook already exists. Thanks to @fmoralesc - see comments below

Reference the [GNU coding standards on error messages](http://www.gnu.org/prep/standards/standards.html#Errors)

FYI, opening a single file at a particular line is already possible with +<linenum>, eg.

```
vi file.c +25
```

@splinterofchaos - the fuzzy matching only kicks in if a file by that name does not exist. 

``` bash
$ ls test:1
test:1
$ vi test:1:2:3
```

would open the file `test:1` on line 2, column 3. Whereas:

``` bash
$ ls trial*
trial
$ vi trial:1:2
```

would open the file `trial` on line 1, column 2.

If anyone cares to take a look, I have a full implementation of acme/sam addresses at https://github.com/fmoralesc/plan9-for-vimspace/blob/master/autoload/plan9/address.vim It translates them from acme's address syntax to viml commands.
@fmoralesc :+1: how do you hook this into file loading via `:e` etc?

@myitcv I don't :P This is plugged to mouse actions, like in acme: https://github.com/fmoralesc/plan9-for-vimspace/blob/master/autoload/acme/actions.vim#L82-L91

I guess you could use FileReadCmd for that, so you can massage the file path?

@fmoralesc - really nice. Does this work in terminal vim? If so, what mouse setting do I need?

And :+1: for pointing out `FileReadCmd` - that should make `file-line` much cleaner. Although now I'm probably going to move to use your project :)

I haven't tested it much in terminal vim (I use gvim most of the time, because I write mostly prose and I need italics and some other niceties which are awkward to set up on terminal vim), so I'm not sure about that. Anyway, the mouse actions can be triggered with the keyboard too. 

I was wrong about `FileReadCmd`, what you most likely need is `BufReadCmd`. I'm exploring how to implement what you proposed, extending this to `:e` and related commands.
@fmoralesc - great, would certainly be interested in the results.

At least for moving to a specific line, this turned out to be very easy to implement:

``` vim
function! AcmeOpen(match)
    let l:match_data = split(a:match, ":")
    let l:path = l:match_data[0]
    let l:line = l:match_data[1] 
    if filereadable(l:path) && !bufexists(l:path)
        bw! "required so we don't pollute the bufferlist
        exe "edit ".l:path
        try
            silent exe l:line
        catch /E486/
        endtry
    endif
endfunction

au! BufReadCmd *:* call AcmeOpen(expand("<amatch>"))
```

This doesn't comply with the full acme/sam addresses spec, obviously, but it's a start. Also, some addresses like `file.c:/method/` aren't even passed to the function, because they are invalid paths for vim, and it is not possible to catch the error in viml.

The error I received there is raised here in neovim's codebase: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/5e65e3eae079d4765124ce791ce79649444ca403/src/nvim/fileio.c#L413-L427 Should neovim make that check, since it seems to be relevant only for DOS/Win95?

@fmoralesc - with the exception of your [latest comment](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/1281#issuecomment-58765144), it feels like we're pretty close to a solution (`BufReadCmd` is the piece of the puzzle I was missing). I've transferred discussion [here](https://github.com/fmoralesc/plan9-for-vimspace/issues/2) for now for anyone interested.

> Should neovim make that check, since it seems to be relevant only for DOS/Win95?

I just tested this on a Windows 7 computer. Odd: `gvim .` works and opens the directory, and `gvim ./` works, opens the directory, and emits "Illegal filename". I wonder if `gvim .` would fail on DOS/Win95, but even though `readfile()` returns here, the directory still gets read. Must happen somewhere else.

I get the same in Linux. Directory reading is all handled by the netrw plugin, so in this case my guess is the autocommand netrw uses (`BufRead`) is still triggered despite readfile failing at that point. I think this is a bug (at least, displaying the error message is), althought most probably people never came into it before for the reasons we are now.
Does https://github.com/kopischke/vim-fetch solve everyone's use cases here?
Should fix if for the simplest case. It still won't be able to support // or # addresses, as required in plan9-form-vimspace ;)
@fmoralesc why don’t you open an issue for that on https://github.com/kopischke/vim-fetch? I’m not familiar with the format, but details provided, I might be able to add it to the plug-in.

@kopischke plan9's sam (which plan9-for-vimspace) has addresses like `main.c#23` (basically, byte 23 at `main.c`) and `main.c/void main/` (search for `void main` at `main.c`) , but iirc vim won't accept `#` or `/` in filenames (it is hardcoded in the source, and the second will even throw an error which can't be catched). 

I think this format is not common enough to make it worth supporting at vim-fetch, though, but if you are interested, you can check [p9fv's address compiler](https://github.com/plan9-for-vimspace/plan9-for-vimspace/blob/master/autoload/plan9/address.vim) and [address handler](https://github.com/plan9-for-vimspace/plan9-for-vimspace/blob/master/autoload/address_handler/address_handler.vim). vim-fetch looks really nice, btw.
@fmoralesc let’s take that discussion to [the issue I just created](https://github.com/kopischke/vim-fetch/issues/2) – I don’t want to hijack this thread.

Would be nice to have for integration with Midnight Commander as well - e.g. I'm using NeoVim as a PAGER/EDITOR - would be very convenient to open needed line directly from the search results: https://midnight-commander.org/ticket/3862

Just to be clear, the suggestion is to use either:
- https://github.com/wsdjeg/vim-fetch
- https://github.com/bogado/file-line

FYI: https://github.com/bogado/file-line is unmaintained for 5+ years and it seems to be broken. If I do `~/.vimrc:42:10` it opens the file in L42 however it doesn't go to C10.

https://github.com/wsdjeg/vim-fetch is working for both cases (line and column).
Closing as plugins already exist to fulfil this functionality.

The default vim behaviour is not great because you can't directly open files that start with a `+` within the terminal.

Sveltekit routing files have special names that start by a `+` for example.

You may think it's dumb to have special characters in filename but in the end the colon notation is less intrusive and more common.

Also both plugins are apparently unmaintained and none is working when installed with the lazy plugin manager

Please consider the reopening of this issue and to deprecate the old vim behaviour
Would be in favor of putting this in core, but someone needs to make a plugin that actually works well. Or say what API is needed to do so.
Does that not contradict the fact that this is issue was previously closed because of supposedly a plugin already implementing the functionanility ?

> The default vim behaviour is not great because you can't directly open files that start with a + within the terminal.
>
> Sveltekit routing files have special names that start by a + for example.

You can get around that by prefixing the filename with `./`. The same goes for files starting with `-`

> Also both plugins are apparently unmaintained and none is working when installed with the lazy plugin manager

https://github.com/bogado/file-line works absolutely fine. I've been using it for years.

The whole plugin is 90LOC. It doesn't matter if it's unmaintained. And either way, something being unmaintained is not a justification for adding it to core.

> https://github.com/bogado/file-line works absolutely fine.

I'll try that, thanks.

This seems like a rather obvious and low-cost feature to have in core, in the same class as e.g. `:help ++p`.

I think if a commenting keymap is not appropriate for core (similar cost, drastically higher value), then I personally think this isn't either.

Either way, since there are concerns about https://github.com/bogado/file-line being unmaintained, I've created a modern Lua equivalent https://github.com/lewis6991/fileline.nvim.
@lewis6991 you're amazing! "1 commit, 1 hour ago" :D

> if a commenting keymap is not appropriate for core (similar cost, drastically higher value)

Is it similar cost? Commenting plugin requires per-filetype maintenance, I don't think that's the case here?

If we can implement a commenting plugin in a minimalist way then let's revisit that.

We already have that with `'comments'` and `'commentstring'`, we just don't have anything that leverages those options.

https://github.com/tpope/vim-commentary/blob/master/plugin/commentary.vim is 120LOC.

To me the whole point of having this in core is the adoption of a better standard for referring to a file location that I think is in line with Neovim's adoption of Lua or integration of the Language Server Protocol. 

The point is to have Neovim behave even better with the outer ecosystem, it is a small thing maybe but very much in line with Neovim's _raison d'être_
This isn't defined anywhere in any spec, so I'd disagree; unlike Lua, LSP, basedir-spec and editorconfig which are properly defined outside Neovim.

Ironically enough, I tried to install your plugin in LunarVim and I got this error :
It works but I do get an error, please pay attention to how the error's location is reported:
```
Error detected while processing BufNewFile Autocommands for "*":
Error executing lua callback: /usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/editorconfig.lua:210: Invalid buffer id: 1
stack traceback:
        [C]: in function 'nvim_buf_get_name'
        /usr/share/nvim/runtime/lua/editorconfig.lua:210: in function 'config'
        /usr/share/nvim/runtime/plugin/editorconfig.lua:11: in function </usr/share/nvim/runtime/plugin/editorconfig.lua:4>
```

Maybe there does not need to be a spec for something that basic ? `path/to/filename:line(:col)`
`gdb` reports file locations like that and so many other, it is a de factor standard

( I think it is totally a coincidence, but even in (neo)vim you can go to a specific line with `:$line` )

This is already fixed in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/23922 but further enforces my point that this isn't such a low cost since it already has unintended interactions with other existing systems in core thus raising the complexity.

I just want to mention that I've been using [vim-fetch](https://github.com/wsdjeg/vim-fetch) since it was brought to my attention earlier in this thread by @justinmk in 2015 and haven't had any problems with it. It is still maintained (last commit was 3 weeks ago).

In addition to supporting `nvim file.cpp:xx[:yy]`, it also supports `:e file.cpp:xx[:yy]` and `gF` on strings matching such a path as well.

With regards to whether there is a spec or not, vim-fetch refers to `file.cpp[:ll[:cc]]` "the gnu colon format", though this representation is certainly not exclusive to GNU. If you generalize it to only line numbers it's pretty much universal across tools/editors on all active platforms today.

There is a possibility of much richer sublanguage for expressing these locations used by [Plan 9 ACME](https://youtu.be/dP1xVpMPn8M?t=548), which I tried to describe in [my blogpost](https://matej.ceplovi.cz/blog/design-notes-on-plan9-for-vimspace.html).

E.g., ACME can do

```
:e filename.txt:/^VIM/
```

would open the file “filename.txt” on the first line starting with the “VIM” string. I believe that keeping this whole thing in Lua, could provide hope that somebody would eventually implement all this craziness.

> With regards to whether there is a spec or not, vim-fetch refers to `file.cpp[:ll[:cc]]` "the gnu colon format", though this representation is certainly not exclusive to GNU

Also vim's own quickfix paradigm essentially depends on this.
Isn't this a very basic capability of the editor? Why do support by a plugin.

milestone.description: Low priority. Not planned for the current target, may be reassigned.
milestone.title: backlog

title: parse colon in path (":<number>") as line number
